title: AB 1850
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aimed at educating the public about the exclusion and internment of Japanese Americans during World War II. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, officials, and historians. The CWRIC concluded that the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was not justified by military necessity, but rather driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. This led to a grave personal injustice for American citizens and resident aliens of Japanese ancestry. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, declaring it a great day for America. The Congress also declared their findings in the act. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during WWII, apologizing for the violation of their civil liberties and constitutional rights. This apology is in response to actions motivated by racial prejudice and wartime hysteria, resulting in significant human suffering and damages. The Congress apologizes for the significant human suffering and damages inflicted on citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during WWII, acknowledging the violation of their civil liberties and constitutional rights. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Legislature intends to create a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would evaluate their knowledge of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal mandates. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop a test to assess the English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government for eligible foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under federal law. The Governor, Superintendent, Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, President pro Tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the Assembly will request approval from the US Immigration and Naturalization Service and Attorney General to use a test for eligible foreign nationals to meet requirements under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of US history and government. Test results will be confidential. The test for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status includes demonstrating English proficiency and knowledge of US history and government. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. School districts and other agencies receiving federal funds must administer the test with appropriate security measures. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to include requirements for administering the test for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status. Section 52613 of the Education Code mandates that school districts charging nonimmigrant foreign nationals for English and citizenship classes must set fees to cover instruction costs, not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be approved by the governing board at least 90 days before classes begin. Section 52651 of the Education Code defines key terms for the chapter, including "Board of Governors," "Chancellor," "Community-based organizations," "Department," and "Educational outreach activities." Educational outreach activities refer to providing information to temporary resident foreign nationals about the requirements of the federal Immigration and Nationality Act of 1986, including adjustment of resident status, sources of assistance, rights and responsibilities, health, employment, and social services. It excludes client counseling or assuming responsibility for the foreign national's application for resident status adjustment. The curr_chunk discusses educational opportunities for immigrants, defining "immigrant" and "newly legalized person" as per California law. The curr_chunk defines "newly legalized person" as a foreign national granted lawful temporary resident status under specific sections of the United States Code, and also includes those who have obtained permanent resident or citizenship status. It also defines "services provider" as approved organizations eligible to provide educational services to newly legalized persons. Additionally, it mentions "SLIAG" as State Legalization Impact-Assistance Grants under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The curr_chunk clarifies the definitions of "SLIAG" and "Superintendent" and amends Section 68062 of the Education Code regarding residency rules. It states that residence is where one stays when not elsewhere for work, cannot be lost until another is gained, and can only be changed by act and intent, with a woman's residence not being dependent on her husband's. Residence rules are clarified in the curr_chunk, stating that a residence cannot be lost until another is gained, can only be changed by act and intent, and a woman's residence is not derivative from her husband's. It also explains how the residence of an unmarried minor is determined. The curr_chunk clarifies that the residence of an unmarried minor cannot be changed by their own act or legal guardian appointment. It also states that a foreign national, including a minor, can establish their residence unless prohibited by federal law. Additionally, the residence of an unmarried minor foreign national is derived from their parents. A minor foreign national's residence is derived from their parents. A student meeting specific requirements is exempt from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and Community Colleges. To qualify for exemption from nonresident tuition at California State University and Community Colleges, a student must have attended a California high school for three or more years, earned credits equivalent to three years of high school coursework, graduated from a California high school or equivalent, and be enrolled in an accredited institution of higher education in California. Additionally, students without lawful immigration status must file an affidavit with the institution stating their intent to legalize their immigration status. In the case of a person without lawful immigration status, filing an affidavit with the institution of higher education stating the student's intent to legalize their immigration status is required. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will establish rules for this exemption, and student information obtained will be kept confidential. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will establish rules and regulations for implementing the section. Student information collected will be confidential. Section 69505 of the Education Code is amended to exempt reparation payments for Japanese internment victims from being considered in determining financial need. The exemption for reparation payments for Japanese internment victims from being considered in determining financial need is contingent on the enactment of specific federal legislation by January 20, 2017. The term "alien" is replaced with "foreign national" for individuals not citizens of the US. "Illegal alien" is replaced with "undocumented foreign national" for those unlawfully present. If the Superintendent certifies, Section 2 of the act becomes inoperative.
